ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was a fascinating class and I learned a lot. Ann is a good lecturer and I think she explains things pretty clearly.However, there was a lot of really dense reading that was difficult to get through with no formal background in forestry. I think a separate discussion section with Marlyse per week would be very helpful.Also, the field trips were somewhat well organized, but in a few cases I think we could have accomplished the same thing in East Rock park. A lot of driving for only, in some cases, 1-2 hours of forest time. I think more thought could be put into the logistics.Also, I think having an assignment, a presentation, field trips AND an in class mid-term and final is a bit much for a 3-credit course. Perhaps cut out one of these. Maybe the presentation. Most of the presentations weren't that well done (from students) and we spent 3 weeks on them...

I loved this course. Partly because I loved the material and partly because I thought Professor Camp did a great job teaching it. There were a few things that I think could be improved, though. First, I didn't think the assignments were particularly useful for understanding the course material. They seemed to be more a means to generate grades for the students than to supplement the lecture material. They were interesting to do, but perhaps they could have been more tailored to tie in with the course material.Second, I would have loved more field trips. That's really where the material came to life and everything made sense.Third, I certainly learned some things from the student presentations in the last several classes of the semester, but I think I would have preferred a few more lectures going deeper into some of the material.

With field trips in particular, it would be really nice to have more field trips closer to Yale. Driving all the way to Harvard Forest is an enormous waste of time when interesting succesion is happening at West Rock and Westwoods. It would be very easy to do a fieldtrip right in Eastrock. The fieldtrips didn't really contribute to the class and seemed like a token. I would love more fieldtrips if they were more connected.
N/A

I wished for a bit more interaction between the instructor and the students. It was clear the course is designed for a smaller group, and I almost wonder if it would have been better if it was capped. Still, I learned a lot and am very thankful I took the course.
it was really nice class

While I greatly appreciate the effort and planning that went into the field trips, I felt like the trip to the Harvard forest and to Great Mountain could have perhaps been a little closer to home. Maybe we could have just gone to East Rock Park for one of them. That being said, they were interesting and I learned something, they just involved a lot of travel compared to on the ground time.

6. Marlyse was an excellent TA. She was very organized, especially considering all of the class field trips, and I really look up to her as a person. My one criticism is that she talks very quickly and uses a lot of jargon that can sometimes do more to confuse than clarify.8. The field trips were very well designed and ran remarkably smoothly. I especially enjoyed the âforest forensicsâ walk with Tom Wessels, and the first trip to Great Mountain!11. Ann is very responsive to student comments. Her great amount of experience in the field means that she has a tremendous number of great (and relevant) anecdotes that help to respond to questions and clarify concepts.14. This class is very valuable to students interested in the applied field/science of forestry, especially to those of us who are interested in working in the northeast or northwest regions of the United States. I could see how some students might argue, however, that there was too little attention toward tropical systems (but this is not a complaint of mine!).

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trips were greatAnne's enthusiasm in trees is evident through her teachingThe subject covered a lot of topics
Lit review, the content of the class, and readings.

It covered a wide range of material, but in just enough detail that you did not feel you were missing key concepts. The practicality of knowledge learned in the class was very apparent and was especially evident when taking the midterm and final. And the field trips were great!
The best aspect of this course was the field trip. By having the field trip, I understood the concept more.
The field trips were incredibly valuable and helped compliment course material.
The Tom Wessels field trip and Marlyse's old growth forest hike were some of my favorite parts. I like Ann's analogies in class.
Field Trips

It is a great broad introduction into forestry especially in North American forestry.It covers the basic essential aspects and helps students to focus their study concentrations in the following semesters.
field trip and all the articles
Class was well structured, and professor was organized for each lecture.
Question 16: field trips, discussion of papers, class review by TA and lectures.

The readings were classics, the content was gone over in a thorough way, and Ann's personal experiences in this field were fascinating. My favorite times were hearing Ann's experiences. I feel like a great part of what I remember were her stories of working out West. Lots of support from the TA as well.Thanks for the great feedback on the presentation. This is the only class I took this semester that actually gave me feedback on a presentation.

One of the best aspects of this course was that it integrated lectures, discussions, field trips, and student presentations. Exploring complex topics from these different angles helped to solidify concepts in my mind, and it kept the class from getting to static. The annotated bibliography was also an extremely beneficial exercise â of all of my classes, I probably learned (and invested) the most in this assignment.

The readings were very appropriate in difficulty and were targeted very well to their respective lectures. For students with backgrounds outside of science, this was a good introduction to critically analyzing and being tested on scientific articles. The structure of the class was great. This was my favorite class of the semester by far!

The conceptual knowledge gained in this course will be extremely helpful for future reference. Also, the management applicability is quite useful. Further, I enjoyed learning the history of the field of stand dynamics through scientific literature. Finally, I feel I learned a great deal through application of conceptual material through application on field trips.

Some of the best aspects of this course were the field trips. They were really helpful for solidifying concepts we learned about in class and in the readings. I also really appreciated how organized the professor was with her slides and her readings. Her organization made it really easy to get ahead with the readings and organize the information for ourselves.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: From not having a background in Forests, this subject was the tougher than the rest. It was difficult to grasp the concepts and the review sessions were not as frequent as they should have been.It would have been better if there was an hour a week review session of all the readings assigned. This way everything is not left to the review session before the exam.The test is highly practical while the class is highly theoretical. For some of us who came with no knowledge in Forests, this was not good for out grades. It is not easily to learn a Science without the basics but then the exam should be on the basics and not on the implications of what the basics mean.If the exam tests our knowledge of understanding, then there should be more compulsory review sessions that speak about "practical knowledge"
I already responded to this in question 15.
See above

The lectures feel slow, repetitive and outdated. There could be a much larger emphasis on other stand models such as Franklin- it's nuts to leave out a major part of forestry education just because of Chad Oliver's political stance. There also needs to be a much larger emphasis on quantitative stand dynamics. The sections on SI, SE, UR, and OG could be done in 1/2 the time, leaving much more time for additional material. The discussions also need to be better organized and perhaps have a lecture for 1/2 of the class then a discussion for the second half. This year they were a huge waste of time.

We seemed to cover most material before the midterm and then go back and mainly review the same material with a bit more detail after the midterm. A better structure may be to spread the material more evenly over the semester.
The course should have more sessions for reading discussion.
The organization of the some of the lectures was weak and the PowerPoints tended to jump from topic to topic a lot.
Instructor feedback wasn't great--again I think this is systematic of having too many students for the class format.
Probably less focus on historical evolution of forestry and more on current-affairs forestry.
TA review sessions were inefficient.
Too many presentations at the end of class two weeks was too long.
Question 17. The mode of assessment. I think the final exam should be cut out and allow for fully synthesized paper submissions that allows for critical thinking in a subject of interest.

We could have spent more time walking around outside, especially during the first couple of months. It felt like a shame to be indoors looking at powerpoint presentations of trees when we're surrounded by such exceptional trees. This was brought home to me the other day when I was walking around in the forest and thinking about the concepts we learned in class: I realized that this was only the second or third time I'd really applied that knowledge (aside from the field trips). We had so many opportunities to go outside and talk about things in the forests around campus.Also, I'm not sure how useful it is to expect people to learn the names of all the authors we read throughout the term. For people in this field, sure, that makes sense. But for others, studying topics somewhat different than forestry, it is an onerous task, and of limited value.I would like to see more feedback on my annotated bibliography.

My only real complaint about the class is the pace. It felt like it moved a little too slowly, especially because the concepts are quite logical and straightforward. I would like to have spent a little more time focusing on applying the concepts (which is where it really gets messy), as we were asked to do in the final exam.

I wish the presentations were tied more closely to class material. The current structure allows students to tap into their varying interests and backgrounds, but I think we would have learned more if we had to step outside our comfort zones. Students tended to present on work they had already done, and it felt more like an exercise in public speaking than learning about forestry concepts.Also, a hands on or demonstrative component could have helped to clarify the quantitative lecture. Even if it isn't run by an expert, that field trip should definitely happen every year.

It would be more helpful to discuss fewer papers but more frequently. I felt that I forgot most of what I had read in the papers before we discussed them in class.Also, I would have loved to have more time in the field. We could have visited the Marsh gardens to learn more about tree architecture or leaf formation instead of just discussing it it class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

The discussion of the readings were a good idea and useful for the most part. For a few of the discussions I had not had time to do the readings beforehand so the discussions were not that helpful, but clearly that was due to my own prioritizing.
It was effective.
N/A
It was highly relevant as principles explained in class were seen in actual field trips.
effective!
Yes

Yes, I really liked the periodic discussions based on the class readings. However, I think they could have been improved if the instructor or TA had supplied some directing or leading questions for the reading. I had a discussion group for another class that took this approach, and the conversations were quicker to develop and felt more productive.

The ratio of time spent between lecture and discussion was fine though, it might be beneficial if we discussed papers once a week instead of talking about a lot of papers every few weeks. I think that the discussions would go better because people will remember the content more if they have read them closer to the time of discussing them.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: She is honest about what she doesn't know and find means of helping resolving. Also, shearticulates very well in subjects of her specialty

Marlyse was a fantastic TA. Despite living so far away, she was very available and also very responsive to email. It was clear that she cared a lot about the students and a lot about the class, and I greatly admire her character. She could be a little disorganized, and sometimes gave complicated or unclear answers to questions. But for the most part, I could rely on her to help whenever I had a problem. After the first field trip with her, I knew she was someone I would aspire to be like! I also thought she did a great job leading the class walk in her neighborhood park in Sandy Hook, and she was very good about organizing the field trips in general.
No complaints about Marlyse--she was perfect!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  The teaching assistant is highly knowledgeable and approachable.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marylse was helpful, and really responsive. I felt like her lectures were sometimes a bit disjointed, however, and sometimes her answers were so open ended I didn't leave with much more clarity. However, she's very competent and clearly very well versed in the material. She did a great job leading some of the field trip site visits, and is also clearly really passionate about her work.When she led reviews/discussions sometimes there wasn't enough structure; she was depending too much on students taking the lead. That's not what I pay for. I would have liked for her to take more of a lead.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse did a great job
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was great and a super-star for dealing with an enormous class.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marylse was extremely knowledgeable on the subjects covered, was constantly accessible and willing to help.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was excellent. She just needs to speak a little bit slower. She speaks so fast!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Very accessible in and outside of class, knowledgeable about the course structure and the material

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  I wished that there was more variety in the times offered for extra review sections and help. If you had meetings or classes right after usually scheduled class time, you were somewhat out of luck.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Punctual, conscientious and dedicated.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  She is really helpful with deep knowledge!

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  TA was good at relaying the "take-home" messages for each concept and reading. Could use some improvement on inspiring students to be more participatory during review sessions.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  The TA was very accessible and shared her interesting perspectives and experiences in class. She really added a lot to our discussions. Her presentation was excellent as well.I'm not sure how to improve her role as a TA; she seemed to have it down pretty well.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was a great teaching assistant. She made a lot of time for review sessions with us which was really helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It's a foundational course for the M.F. program
It's a great fit, although doesn't go into as much depth as I would like. It does a particularly good job bringing everyone up to the same baseline.
I aim to learn on forest management during my study here. This course provided me the basic knowledge on forest management.
Good course not only for forestry students, but anyone who is interested in how ecosystem develop over a temporal and spatial scale
See answer to question 21
It is an essential component of the MF course, especially as I do not have specific forestry education.
Course gave me a good background in forest development in general, which will be useful in applications to forest restoration.
The course is vital to my research interests
I may end up switching to the MF degree. I enjoyed the course material and the students taking the course. Regardless, I feel like I learned something tangible that I can use.
As an MF candidate, this is a great foundational course that will undoubtedly help in future classes, such as Silviculture, Management Plans, Forest Health, and others.

This class should be required of all MF candidates, especially those with no formal training in forestry. I had only ever dealt with forestry from a policy perspective, and this was a great intro to the technical aspects of forestry.

This course provides fundamental knowledge for both science based and management based tracts. I think this course, while geared for foresters, could be useful for anyone interested in environmental studies.

This course fits into my overall program at school because I am trying to gain the skills to work in and conserve New England forests. This class taught me how to look at a forest both as an ecologist and manager which will be very helpful in whatever job I choose after graduating.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about forests and it does teach you that.
It was a foundational course for the M.F. program.
Essential for a forestry education.
I heard that if you're only going to take one Forestry course while at FES, it was the course to take and after taking it, I completely agree.
I took this course because the course is very important for me to understand forest management.
Recommended by older student
I was interested in potentially going to graduate school for forestry but had no forestry knowledge.
I wanted a better understanding of forest dynamics and I thought it would be a good prerequisite for silviculture.
It suited my academic goals.
It is one of my requirement
Recommended by my advisor.
To enable me grasp concepts in preparation for my research

It looked like an interesting introduction to a topic that I didn't have much direct experience with. I had heard that Ann was a good teacher. Also, the readings looked excellent (which they mostly were).

I took Stand Dynamics because I thought it might fit in well with my long-term aspirations to become a forester in the Northeast or Mid-Atlantic region. I had heard that the class provides a good background for understanding other forestry-related classes/topics. Having taken the class now, I completely agree!

I took this course out of curiosity. Also, I heard it would be helpful in preparation for silviculture. I found that this course helped bridge what I have previously observed with conceptual knowledge.
I took this course because I wanted to learn more about forest ecology particularly in temperate regions.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes it did add skills but there should be more practical review sessions
Yes, they did. I just think consideration needs to be paid to the sheer volume of technical reading that is required and how to better integrate it into the class.
Yes, I felt like I was learning new things every day.
Yes, but not as much depth as I would like.
Yes, the knowledge gained from the course exceeded my expectations.
The knowledge that I gained from the course met my expectations.
Yes
Absolutely. I didn't know anything about forestry or stand dynamics, and this was a great introduction.
Yes. I do think the Oliver Larson book should be required reading. It was so helpful after I read it.
Yes.
Yes more than my expectation
Yes, far and beyond.
Yes

Yes, aside from not having enough time to really put them into practice out in the forest. This is a foundational course for people interested in forests, whether or not they plan to actually work in forests.
Yes, the knowledge gained from the course met my expectations; I only wish it would have moved a little bit faster so that we could have covered more.
Absolutely! I can only hope I learn as much in other forestry classes as I did in Stands.
Yes.
This class did meet my expectations. I learned a lot and I feel like I now look at forests differently and have a better understanding of how trees grow and interact overtime.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: There was no group work
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
Allowed for interaction between students of different backgrounds in co-learning.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: For those that have already done basic Env. Science, this course will be wonderful but for those who have not studied forests before, be prepared to put in extra hours to learn the implications of what is being taught in order to get a better grade

Be prepared for a lot of reading. Participate and ask clarifying questions. Start your annotated bibliography EARLY. Study a lot for the mid-term and final, well in advance, because they are really difficult.

I essentially never opened the Stand Dynamics textbook. I'm glad to have it as a reference for the future, but the course draws directly from the book in many cases, to the point where reading the book would have been almost superfluous. I can't say that is true for the whole book since I only read a few chapters.

Make sure that your Lit. Review is well planned and work on it throughout the semester. Get the basics of these models from the class, and then do your own reading / research for the rest of the material.
Focus on linking concepts learned in class to what you see at field trips and the field trips will be very useful, not just fun.
Manage your time very well to read all of the journals.
Do the readings and participate in discussions
Read Oliver and Larson early in the course. Ann follows the format of the book closely and it will give you a good grounding for her lectures.
The textbook should be a requirement
A lot of reading is necessary.
Try to understand broad picture (not detail!)
Do it.
Preparation before lecture is critical, this includes text readings, and review of slide presentations. Must be prepared for class.
Students should endeavour to read all reading papers

Learn to take notes on the readings. You will need to refer to them multiple times throughout the course and I spent a lot of time rereading things I had forgotten and neglected to annotate. Also, choose topics for your project and presentation that fit with your other coursework. I chose topics that did not relate to my other studies and it was an immense amount of work trying to get up to speed on them. I would have been better served integrating my coursework to a greater extent.

I would strongly advise you to take the course. And even though the Forest Stand Dynamics text is not required reading, I recommend reading it as the course progresses. It provides nice continuity from topic to topic, and the writing is very accessible. I would also recommend going on all of the field trips for this class â each one is different and useful in its own way. Plus, itâs a great way to get to know the professor and hear all of her awesome stories!
Even if you're not an MF, take the course anyway. You'll be surprised how much you learn!
Keep up on the readings. They are extremely helpful. Also, think in terms of management and application when it comes to conceptual material.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students. It was taught very well and in a way that is easy to understand. Also, this is great background for people interested in business or a good foundational course for people interested in forest ecology or management.
